definition: lit. to sing “The Empty City Stratagem” (idiom)/fig. to put up a bluff to conceal one's weakness/(jocularly) (of a place etc) to be empty/(of one's stomach) to be rumbling
to sing/to call loudly/to chant
empty/air/sky/in vain
to empty/vacant/unoccupied/space/leisure/free time
city walls/city/town/CL:座[zuo4],道[dao4],個|个[ge4]
surname Ji
to calculate/to compute/to count/to regard as important/to plan/ruse/meter/gauge
the empty city stratagem (in which Zhuge Liang presents himself as unperturbed while making it evident that his city is undefended, hoping his adversary will suspect an ambush)/double bluff
sound made by an empty stomach
to feed to the full/to cram
stomach rumbling with hunger
to seize a camp/to surprise the enemy in bed
riders tired and horses weary (idiom)/worn out/exhausted/spent/fatigued
to eat one's fill
to beat the gong to recall troops (idiom); to order a retreat
to be hungry/hungry/to starve (sb)
to wait at one's ease for the exhausted enemy/to nurture one's strength and bide one's time (idiom)
to fall into a trap/taken in by a stratagem/cheated/ripped off
to leave in stealth/to slip away
to start a war/to open hostilities
to go hungry/to starve
to steal away/to beat it
to take advantage of sb's misfortune/to loot
